data.output: The recommendation letter had been on his desk for a couple of weeks now, and he was staring at it, wondering if being honest about Tom's violent outbursts was the right thing to do. He had just asked his assistant to schedule the letter to be picked up by the courier. Tom will never get into the program if he gets to send the letter. He would have put a stamp and seal for him never to see his daughter again. "Can I ignore the violent outbursts? Can he be a better man?" It was a decision he had to make.

Stamp prices are really expensive. There was a letter that was received by someone and they were interested in how much it cost the sender to send it. They researched how much the specific stamp used cost the sender and they were shocked at the price. They remember when stamps used to be really cheap. It made them realise one of the reasons why less letters are sent by post.

I clicked "Send email" and I shut down my computer. I felt exhausted, and I wanted to go to bed. Writing emails always drained the life out of me, and I'd written over 20 emails in one day, spanning morning to evening. I'd also been to the post office to send a letter to my friend over in America. I was stupid and forgot to write the zip code, so the person at the desk told me off. But it was lucky he caught it in time. He gave me a receipt on which he took a stamp and stampp

I picked up the initial stamp, carved with an ornate letter 'P' and pressed it into the hot wax that sealed the intensely personal letter firmly closed, safe from prying eyes. It maybe seemed like an old fashioned, outdated way to send a message but who knows where emails or whatsapps end up these day. A wax sealed letter, delivered by Uber  was the modern day messenger courier

Today I wrote a heartfelt letter to my best friend, telling her all about the things I had gone through as of late. I sealed it up and hurried to the post office, excited to send it as this was my first letter I had written and I wanted to start exchanging letters as it felt so novel! But in a rush, I forgot to put a stamp on the envelope. Weeks went by, and my friend never got the letter. I wondered where it had gone, everyday asking her if she had received anything nice lately not wanting to ruin the surprise but a feeling of melancholy if this may have been a sign not to do this.

Josie was a quiet girl who lived in a small village and had a hobby as a stamp collector. Her dad worked in the local post office so she had access to lots of stamps and loved seeing all the different types on the letters that came though the post office, although she would never use any of her stamp collection on normal letters herself, they were too special to her. When letters would be returned to the post office when a letter couldn't be posted, her father would send the old stamps her way.

The newest member of the stamp club blitzed through the school corridor in an attempt to make a punctual start to his time at the club. In the event of this rush, he dropped his most valuable stamp as it slipped out of his book beyond the boy's knowledge. 2 hours later, he made his way back to same route he took, only to find that somebody else had already used his stamp to send off a letter.

"Thanks for listening and please send your friends to the show!" Ellis said to the audience. Ellis had just completed her first one-woman show of her tour, and the show was called 'A letter to my younger self'. She was so proud of herself, she hadn't let production interfere too much and her personal stamp remained well and truly on the show.

They marched along, stamping their feet to the words. the rhymthing then changed, slowing, and their boots crunched to the ground for each letter of the word. S-E -N -D. T-H-E-M. H-O-M-E. Watching as they went past we wondered - send who home?

I stamp my feet in outrage and send my brother for help. My mother appears with a weary look on her face. It is not the first time that my name has been misspelled. I stare at the antagonising letter .

Emma wanted to send a message to the public about climate change. She felt that people were not taking the subject seriously, and she wanted to do something about it, drawing as much attention as possible to the issue. Emma visited her local craft store, where she bought giant stamps for every letter of the alphabet, and colourful inks to suit. On her walk home, Emma stamped important and significant messages on the sides of buildings, in the middle of the streets, on public benches and bins, to spread the word about climate change.

on a typical day on the emerald isle, the boy woke up and started staring at the clock as if the pendulum was a time stamp of his existence constantly ticking at the back of his neck. then he remembered he just missed his application to a new flat just because of one missing reference letter. he was one step away from being homeless. in a hurry, he grabbed his phone and checked if a friend of his did send the money he was in need of for a quite long time.

As he sent the email, the screen went blank and Jon knew something was wrong.  Since receiving that letter from an anonymous sender, things had gone from bad to worse. The letter said the sender had incriminating evidence on Jon, and unless he did exactly what they asked, it would be publicly shared. He didn't know what dirt they had on him, but he could guess. A self-confessed miser, Jon never affixed a stamp to any of his letters, instead making the recipient pay for the privilege of receiving his communications.

Julia awoke to a 'stamp stamp stamp' from the above flat for the third day in a row! She decided to send for the warden, she had had enough of it! When the warden turned up she knew she would be polite but in her mind she would be full of extremetieis all in capital letters!

I can't believe he just broke up with me, and even worse he broke up with me over text! My phone pinged and all I saw was the letter for his initials pop up on my text screen. Not even a curtsy call or anything, he simply wrote "This isn't working, it's over" and hit send. I shouldn't have expected anything more as he certainly doesn't get the stamp of approval from my parents.

I wanted the passport to escape. To escape from a country where my liberties would be impeded. I had already spent months trying to fulfil their pre-requisites. The accompanying letter had been sent with the passport application a week earlier, but now in the High Commission office, they were telling me that my application was not complete. Not satisfactory. I would have to re-send it but more than that they required a personalised stamp from the solicitor who had attested to the fact they knew me. How very drole I thought. Perhaps ironic that even the British passport office did not expect me to jump through such hoops. I wondered if the process was worth the effort. Should I stay after all?

There is something special about writing a letter, a real letter, not an email or a text message. Taking the time to sit down, place a sheet of paper on my desk, choose from one of my favourite pens and just write whilst sipping a cup of coffee. The bit I like best is the satisfaction of inserting the letter in an envelope, licking the glue, sealing it and then choose a stamp from my collection that I know the recipient will like. I get up, put my shoes on, take my letter and go on a walk around the local park until I spot the very unusual letterbox where a tree has grown to engulf it and I send my letter by posting it through the red letterbox. If this isn't slow living to enjoy the present I don't know what is.

Jaycee finished writing with a flourish. Finished! Finally her book on hi-vis jackets and when to where them is complete. She quickly grabbed her 'complete' stamp and satisfyingly stamped it in her diary. She quickly thought about the e-mail she had to send about quitting work now that she was going to be a highly paid author but decided to complete it later. She needed to chase up that letter she should have received from the police about her speeding ticket first.

The letter sat amongst others on the mat at the empty house, i was about to show to the clients.     The musty smell around the house was tickling my nose and i could see spiders.  Should I stamp on them or pick them up with one of the letters and send them on their way in the garden.

My partner the bedroom window open during the night to let some cold air in, upon doing so a massive spider scurried in through into the bedroom. This would usually send my partner into a panic but this time she grabbed a letter and gathered it up into a glass and threw it outside. Normally she would send me to stamp on it.

There was no stamp on the letter. It is being held at the local post office, waiting for jane to arrive and pay for the delivery. This annoyed jane, as she couldn't understand who would send one, let alone without a stamp on it.

Stamp, stamp, stamp. All day Lucy would sit at her little bank desk stamping approvals on loans, mortgages and other banking products. At the end of each day, she would take the letters over to Michael to send to clients. Michael was Lucy's crush and had been since she started at the company 6 years ago. Today however, was different, today she would tell him how she felt.
It was 2040 and Marly was sat at the breakfast table with her robot. "Many years ago, we could only send a letter if we had a stamp. Nobody uses stamps any more."

Jonny was a quiet child. Mostly he liked to play with lego in front of the fire. He did not like doing the homework tasks sent home by his school. He found them confusing and difficult and dull. Jonny's parents decided that he should try to do his homework as soon as he got home from school and there would be no lego until he'd finished. Jonny hated this idea. "I'm tired when I get home. Why can't I play lego and then do my homework?"  "Because you need to learn your times tables. It's important"  Johnny found it really difficult to adjust to this new routine, dragging his feet on the way home and sometimes getting so annoyed he would stamp his feet and cry. Then he became reluctant to go to school at all and his parents started to become afraid to send him in, knowing there would be a battle over homework. One day after school, Jonny's parents found a letter from school in his schoolbag asking for a meeting.

It was results day, I studied so hard with my friend Ben. The teacher passed out the exam papers. When mine was placed in front of me I saw it was stamped with a large letter 'A'. I took my phone out under the desk to send Ben a message with the good news.

They had a love for beauty, of things done and action taken. The stamp was a special one, an anniversary stamp for a major national event. Eventually they'd send the letter, but in this case it was about appreciating the event and process. It was a lovely gesture for someone they cared deeply about.

since i was 5 years old i have been collecting stamps in a lovely leather bound book, each year i add to my collection with various limited addition stamps. My mother and I love to look through the book at christmas time and see what different images and stamps have been collected. Sometimes for very special family members birthdays I select a stamp from my collection and i use to it send a letter. I like to choose and envelope colour which really sets off the design of the stamp and i hope very much that the recipient is appreciative of the choice and enjoys opening the special letter.

The stamp was clean, unused and valid, but too small a denomination for the letter I had written. This rendered the stamp utterly useless but I did not want to waste it. So, I opened up my finished letter, and used it as a basis to write a much shorter note, which rendered the missive lighter, and the stamp was now useful. Of course, it was now destined elsewhere, and my original letter was unsent. But I chose to send the shorter letter and decided to hold on to the longer one until my correspondent's next birthday!

Whilst marking my pupil's test scores, I use a different colour stamp based on their performance. If they have done well, the stamp is green. If they have done poorly, the stamp is red and I send the student to an after school revision class. To get permission for this, I must get a permission letter signed by their parents.

As I was preparing to send my gifts out, I walked up to the door of the post office and noticed a letter lying on the ground. It had the most beautiful stamp design on the corner, I'd never seen anything like it. I then looked closer and with sudden shock realized it was addressed to me. I took a sharp breath in and looked around to see if there was anyone i knew nearby, I was the only person there, so I quickly popped it into my bag, to open it as soon as I got home.

"Stamp your name up in the stars!" Was it an old song a friend of mine used to sing? I tried to remember his name, but it was gone in the mist of time. My memory was getting worse, then I remembered the last letter he sent me. Did I send a reply?

The Hudson's little boy loved the postman arriving. While he never needed to send any letters, he did love receiving his parent's ones. As soon as a letter arrived, he thanked the postman and peeled off the stamp, sticking it into his notebook, where he got to practice writing envelopes.

The dogs were pulling the sleigh hard. It was already very late and she had to be on time at the post office to send the letter, otherwise she could miss the deadline. She received an award for her book about life in Alaska, and she had to be there for the ceremony. The stamp was getting wet because the dogs went straight through a big pile of snow. She led them through there, as she was so excited to get on time that she completely forgot about the storm that happened last night. Aw, just saw I should have written about something else.  I'm confused of all the letters my mothers has collected over the years. They are from a royal family member. It's weird, as most people send letters, not collect them, or collect stamps. I remember seeing a hug

On Friday morning, just before work, Harry went downstairs from his room to see he had received a letter. On the letter was a 1st class stamp and Harry's first and last name in big, bold letters which automatically let Harry know this letter was urgent. Harry quickly opened the letter and saw it was a letter from his great Aunt letter letting him know he should remember to send the mini fridge she sent him as it was the only fridge she had.
My friend asked me to post a letter. I said no. I didn't expect it to send her into a rage and make her stamp her feet.

He tore up the letter into small pieces and threw it on the ground, stamping it into the mud for good measure. He felt his face redden with anger and conciously tried to calm himself down. To be honest though, the reponse he had got was enough to send anyone into a rage. He glanced up and saw the group of girls across the street, giggling and whispering, making no effort to disguise their behaviour. That was the last time he followed his therapist's idea of expressing his feelings in writing to a girl he liked.
